data.question: How is Reddit responding to the recent news that Is there any electrical engineering alumni in MSU give suggestions on EE internship on Michigan??
data.answer: Graduated with an EE degree last May. Internships my Freshman year were difficult due to Covid. Sophomore year, I went to the career fair (was virtual) and scheduled as many one-on-ones as I could. I had a couple of different offers but went with the one that worked best for me. Always go to the Fall career fair, because you have the highest chance of landing an internship/job (not always the case but was for me).

data.question: How is Reddit responding to the recent news that Is there any electrical engineering alumni in MSU give suggestions on EE internship on Michigan??
data.answer: LinkedIn is your friend! Also hit up an advisor, they might have some leads

data.question: How is Reddit responding to the recent news that Is there any electrical engineering alumni in MSU give suggestions on EE internship on Michigan??
data.answer: Recent graduate here, what I did to help get myself internship opportunities was to get as much experience as possible. There are plenty of design clubs/teams and research you can get involved with on campus. Depending on what you join, you could possibly have recruiters reaching out to you.

data.question: How is Reddit responding to the recent news that Is there any electrical engineering alumni in MSU give suggestions on EE internship on Michigan??
data.answer: Use your connections.  It’s how I’ve gotten almost every job.  Just ask around if you know of anyone within the EE industry.

data.question: How is Reddit responding to the recent news that Will I get in??
data.answer: you’ll probably get waitlisted, if you do send in a letter of continued interest it’ll help your chances of
